rsbNotes.title: Acts 23:16
rsbNotes.text:
23:16 the son of Paul’s sister. Evidently some members of Paul’s family were in Jerusalem.

told Paul. Prisoners received their necessary supplies from relatives and friends who regularly visited them.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 23:23–24
rsbNotes.text: 23:23, 24 Heavily equipped infantry and cavalry delivered Paul safely to Felix, the procurator of the imperial province of Judea. The official provincial headquarters was at Caesarea.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 23:26
rsbNotes.text: 23:26 governor Felix. Felix was a former slave, and as a freedman had ascended to an influential position in the Roman government. In a.d. 52, the emperor Claudius sent him as governor to Caesarea. Felix was addressed as “most excellent Felix” (24:2) during his eight-year administration. The Roman historian Tacitus said that Felix “occupied the office of a king while having the mind of a slave, saturated with cruelty and lust” (History 5.9).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 23:31
rsbNotes.text: 23:31 Antipatris. A town built by Herod the Great in honor of his father, Antipater, about thirty miles northwest of Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 23:35
rsbNotes.text: 23:35 Herod’s praetorium. The official residence built by Herod the Great. It became a Roman praetorium or official residence and included prisoners’ cells (John 18:28; Phil. 1:13).
